Data.term: Question 1 In Lean software development, how can amplifying learning occur? (Select all that apply)
Data.definition: The developers use short iterations.   The developers make different solutions, each with the exact same features.

Data.term: How can waste arise in software development? (Select all that apply)
Data.definition: There are product defects found late in the development.   Developers work on rarely used product features.

Data.term: In Lean software development, what does the principle of "defer commitment" mean?
Data.definition: Decisions are made after having enough information from considering the alternatives.

Data.term: In Lean software development, what does the principle of "deliver fast" mean? (select 2 that apply)
Data.definition: Iterations are short, so feedback is frequent, and product evolution is rapid.   A simpler version of software product (an MVP - Minimum Viable Product) is developed first to reach the market rapidly.

Data.term: Which of the following align with the lean principle of "build quality in"? (select 2 that apply)
Data.definition: The developers refactor the source code to be simpler and easier to modify.   The developers apply practices to avoid or quickly catch errors while making the software product.

Data.term: In Lean software development, what does "optimize the whole" mean? (Select all the apply)
Data.definition: Rather than trying to optimize one part, look at the whole system for optimization opportunities.   The ability of a system to achieve its purpose depends on how well the parts work together, not just how well they perform individually.

Data.term: Which of the following tools can help you find waste in a process?
Data.definition: Value Stream Mapping

Data.term: What are some of the tools to amplify learning? (Select all that apply)
Data.definition: Iteration   Set Based Development   Daily Builds and Smoke Tests

Data.term: How do you deliver fast (i.e reduce cycle time) without compromising the quality?
Data.definition: Minimize the number of items in-process.

Data.term: "The Last Responsible Moment" is a tool for which Lean Software Principle?
Data.definition: Defer Commitment

Data.term: Lean helps increase productivity by:
Data.definition: Reducing the amount of useless activity that our resources (the team members) are currently burdened with.

Data.term: Which practices waste time during software development? (Choose two)
Data.definition: Delays in receiving work products.   Weekly meetings that are held whether or not they are needed.

Data.term: The 5 "Whys" to be considered during a Root Cause Analysis are...?
Data.definition: Why, Why, Why, Why and Why

Data.term: What is the purpose of the Lean tool 'Kaizen'?
Data.definition: An improvement activity to create more value and remove waste.

Data.term: Which of the following can be used to do 5 Whys analysis?
Data.definition: A fishbone diagram

Data.term: In Kanban, a developer pulls the next item to work on from the:
Data.definition: previous column on the board

Data.term: You are a developer on a team using a Kanban board to manage flow. You work on Step X within the process and it just so happens that you are looking for more work. The Kanban board is set up as follows: +Step X has a WIP limit of 3. +Step X is divided into "Doing" and "Done." +The number of items in the "Doing" column is 2. +The number of items in the "Done" column is 1. Without violating the rules of the Kanban board, what should you do? Select all that apply.
Data.definition: Help the group (that picks work from the following column) finish their work so they can pull an item from the "Done" column of Step X. That will allow you to pick an item from the previous step.   Talk to the team about adjusting the WIP limit because increasing the WIP limit will create a better flow of work.

Data.term: Which of the following statements are true about Value Stream Mapping? Select all that apply.
Data.definition: Cycle Time is the total time taken for Value Stream.   Value-added activities are activities that add value from the customer perspective.

Data.term: What is the formula to calculate the Process Cycle Efficiency?
Data.definition: Value Added Time / Cycle Time

Data.term: What is the main goal of the Build-Measure-Learn Cycle?
Data.definition: To go through the build-measure-learn cycle as fast as possible.

Data.term: What do we mean by Validated Learning?
Data.definition: Validating the assumptions by conducting an experiment and collecting data.

Data.term: Which of the following are principles of Lean startup? Select all that apply.
Data.definition: Entrepreneurs are everywhere   Innovation Accounting   Validated Learning

Data.term: Which of the following are true about Lean Startup? Select two.
Data.definition: It relies on actual data rather than gut feelings to validate assumptions or ideas.   It is based on going through the Build-Measure-Learn cycle as fast as you can.

Data.term: Why are traditional management principles ill-suited to the world of startups?
Data.definition: Because startups face chaos and uncertainty.

Data.term: When a startup 'pivots', what is it doing?
Data.definition: Employing a revised strategy in an attempt to achieve its vision.

Data.term: According to Ries, which of the following adjectives describes good startup metrics? Select all that apply.
Data.definition: Accessible   Actionable   Auditable

Data.term: Which of the following are levels of Pirate Metrics? Select all that apply.
Data.definition: Revenue   Referral   Retention   Activation   Acquisition

Data.term: Which of the following are true about Pivot or Persevere? Select two.
Data.definition: Customer segment pivot: The product hypothesis is partially confirmed; it solves the right problem but for a different customer than originally anticipated.   Platform pivot: A change from an application to a platform or vice versa.

Data.term: How do Vanity metrics prevent/inhibit pivoting?
Data.definition: Vanity metrics allow entrepreneurs to draw incorrect conclusions. Based on these metrics, they assume that the product is going in the right direction when it really isn't.

Data.term: What are three ways that a past customer can drive sustainable growth?
Data.definition: Word-of-mouth referral   As side advertising due to usage of the product   Repeat purchase

Data.term: What are the characteristics of "Early Adopters"?
Data.definition: Early adopters will give you their time and honest feedback.   Early adopters are actively seeking a solution to the problem your product solves.

Data.term: What are leap-of-faith assumptions?
Data.definition: Assumptions that are the riskiest elements of a startup plan.

Data.term: Which of these attributes are favored by Lean startup? Select two.
Data.definition: Experimentation and Iteration   Customer feedback

Data.term: Who is an "Intrapreneur" ?
Data.definition: A manager who promotes innovations within the company.

Data.term: Which of the following are true about Design Thinking? Select 2.
Data.definition: It is a process for creative problem solving.   It recommends that a cross-functional team work together in the design thinking process.

Data.term: In design thinking, what are two of the main reasons to empathize with users?
Data.definition: To prevent team member bias from impacting their understanding of the problem and influencing the solution.   To discover the real problem to be solved.

Data.term: Design thinking results in innovation by integrating which three things?
Data.definition: Business Viability   Technical Feasibility   Human Desirability

Data.term: What are the two dimensions for categorizing assumptions?
Data.definition: Probability that it will be wrong   Impact on our solution if it is wrong

Data.term: What are the two dimensions for categorizing tests?
Data.definition: Quality of data collected from the test   Cost/Effort of conducting a test
